references.B05LAN01USGP: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
references.B05ANT04USGP: Anthony, C.D. 2005. Plethodon albagula Grobman 1944: Western Slimy Salamander. Pp. 788-789. In: Lannoo, M. (Ed.), Amphibian Declines: The Conservation Status of United States Species. University of California Press. Berkeley and Los Angeles, California.

references.N81CRO01USGP: Crowell, R.L. 1981. Microhabitat selection and feeding ecology of troglophilic plethodontid salamanders in northwestern Arkansas. Ph.D. dissertation. University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, Arkansas.
references.B29NOB01USGP: Noble, G.K. and B.C. Marshall. 1929. The breeding habits of two salamanders. American Museum Novitates, Number 347, American Museum of Natural History, New York.
references.B87JOH01NAUS: Johnson, T. R. 1987. The amphibians and reptiles of Missouri. Missouri Department of Conservation, Jefferson City. 368 pp.
references.B04TRA01USGP: Trauth, S. E., H. W. Robison, and M. V. Plummer. 2004. The amphibians and reptiles of Arkansas. University of Arkansas Press.
references.B87GAR01NAUS: Garrett, J. M., and D. G. Barker. 1987. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 225 pp.

habitat_description: Adult habitat for the Western slimy salamander includes "damp ravines, wooded hillsides (Johnson, 1987), cave entrances (Crowell, 1981), wooded canyons, and ravines of the Edwards Plateau, Texas (Grobman, 1944)" (Anthony 2005). Breeding habitats include adult habitat as well as abandoned mines where egg deposition has been recorded (Noble and Marshall 1929, Wells and Gordon 1958, Heath et al. 1986, Trauth et al. 2003). For cover, they use rocks and downed logs along moist wooded hillsides, woody ravines, and floodplains and shale banks of streams and rivers (Johnson 1987, Garrett and Barker 1987).
